review.title: Triaging Content Severity in Online Mental Health Forums
review.abstract: Mental health forums are online communities where people express their issues and seek help from moderators and other users. In such forums, there are often posts with severe content indicating that the user is in acute distress and there is a risk of attempted self-harm. Moderators need to respond to these severe posts in a timely manner to prevent potential self-harm. However, the large volume of daily posted content makes it difficult for the moderators to locate and respond to these critical posts. We present a framework for triaging user content into four severity categories which are defined based on indications of self-harm ideation. Our models are based on a feature-rich classification framework which includes lexical, psycholinguistic, contextual and topic modeling features. Our approaches improve the state of the art in triaging the content severity in mental health forums by large margins (up to 17% improvement over the F-1 scores). Using the proposed model, we analyze the mental state of users and we show that overall, long-term users of the forum demonstrate a decreased severity of risk over time. Our analysis on the interaction of the moderators with the users further indicates that without an automatic way to identify critical content, it is indeed challenging for the moderators to provide timely response to the users in need.

metadata.title: Triaging Content Severity in Online Mental Health Forums∗

sections.text: Mental health forums are online communities where people express their problems and seek help from moderators and other users. In such forums, there are often posts with serious content that indicates that the user is in acute distress and is at risk of attempted self-harm. Moderators must respond to these serious posts in a timely manner to prevent potential self-harm. However, the large amount of content posted daily makes it difficult for moderators to locate and respond to these critical posts. We present a framework for dividing user content into four levels of severity, defined on the basis of evidence of an idealization of self-harm. Our models are based on a feature-rich classification framework that includes lexical, psycholinguistic, contextual, and theme-based modeling functionality. Our approaches improve the state of the art by increasing the severity of content in mental health forums by large margins (up to 17% improvement over the F-W1 trim).

sections.heading: 3 Severity Triaging
sections.text: Our main goal is to determine the severity of posts in the mental health forum on the basis of signs of 1Term Frequency - Inverse Document Frequencyself-harm thoughts in the content. Trying out the severity of the content enables moderators to deal with serious cases in a timely manner and hopefully prevent a potential self-harm attempt. Our approach to determining the severity of the content is a supervised learning framework. In the following, we first define the severity levels, then explain the features we use for the classification, and finally, describe the learning algorithm.

sections.heading: 3.1 Severity categories
sections.text: We consider the following 4 severity levels for the content of the posts as defined by (Milne et al., 2016): • Green - posts that show no signs or discussions of self-harm and therefore do not require direct input from the moderators. • Red - posts that indicate that the user is in acute distress and moderators should take care of them as quickly as possible. • Crisis - posts that indicate that the user is in imminent danger of injuring himself. These posts could be the authors themselves or someone the author of the post knows. Moderators should give priority to these cases over all others. sections.heading: 4.1 Data
sections.text: The data we use in this research are forum posts from ReachOut.com, which is a very large and popular mental health forum in Australia and receives approximately 1.8 annual visits (Millen, 2015).While this forum provides a discussion platform for common topics such as life, family and friendship, its main purpose is to support discussions on more critical topics such as addiction, sexuality, identity and mental health issues. Most users and visitors are young people between the ages of 14 and 25. ReachOut employs several high-level moderators as well as younger people who are committed to moderating the forum. These moderators focus on cases that require attention and seek to help these individuals by engaging in the discussion, compressing and showing links and resources to the individuals.We use a subset of the ReachOut forum with 65,755 posts, of which 1,188 were classified as problematic by moderators, based on 4 different categories of severity data. The separate set of test entries includes 2 sets, each of which were written in July 2012 and 2 sets of school events, with the dates of each.

sections.heading: 4.2 Evaluation
sections.text: Following Milne et al. (2016), we use the accuracy and F-1 values to evaluate the classification performance to directly compare the performance of our approach to the state of the art. To aggregate the values for each category, Milne et al. (2016) used the macro average of the F values for the non-green (critical) categories as the official measurement for the CLPsych 2016 shared task. This measurement emphasizes the importance of triaggregation between the critical categories. They also take into account the F-1 and accuracy values for the binary classification of FLAGGED (i.e. KRISE, RED, AMBER) vs. GREEN and DRINGENT (i.e. KRISE, RED) vs. Non-URGENT categories to capture the performance of the systems in the identification of critical posts. We also use these additional measurements to further evaluate the performance of our approach.

sections.heading: 4.3 Baselines and comparison
sections.text: We compare our methods with the four most powerful systems out of a total of 16 participating teams in the CLPsych 2016 Shared Task. To better evaluate our methods, we also consider a simple baseline that is the SVM classifier with uniform and Bigram wordbag characteristics extracted from the body of the post (details can be found in the Methods section).

sections.heading: 6 Conclusions
sections.text: Testing the severity of the content helps forum moderators identify the critical cases and deal with them as quickly as possible. We used a feature-rich classifier with various sets of features, including psycholinguistic, contextual, topic-based modeling, and forum metadata functions, to categorize the content into different categories of severity. In addition to a single classifier, we also built an ensemble classifier using different groups of features. We evaluated our approach using data from ReachOut.com, a large mental health forum. We showed that our state-of-the-art approaches can be effectively improved by large margins (up to 17% macro-average F1 values of critical categories). We showed that the content severity of users "content tends to decrease as they interact with the forum, and the results showed that there is a need for effective and efficient compilation of forum data to help moderators with the health impacts of users.

metadata.abstractText: Mental health forums are online communities where people express their issues and seek help from moderators and other users. In such forums, there are often posts with severe content indicating that the user is in acute distress and there is a risk of attempted self-harm. Moderators need to respond to these severe posts in a timely manner to prevent potential selfharm. However, the large volume of daily posted content makes it difficult for the moderators to locate and respond to these critical posts. We present a framework for triaging user content into four severity categories which are defined based on indications of self-harm ideation. Our models are based on a feature-rich classification framework which includes lexical, psycholinguistic, contextual and topic modeling features. Our approaches improve the state of the art in triaging the content severity in mental health forums by large margins (up to 17% improvement over the F-1 scores). Using the proposed model, we analyze the mental state of users and we show that overall, long-term users of the forum demonstrate a decreased severity of risk over time.
